text:

This blog documents the design of increasingly complex AI agents — not as models in a paper, but as characters in a world. You will hopefully see my successes, but more often you will see my failures.

title: ailo-blog
text:
👽 Who Is the Martian?
Back in middle school, my Physics teacher told me the only way to understand something was to pretend you were explaining it to a man from Mars.
I’ve never forgotten that.
At the end of every post you’ll find a Martian Mode 👽. This is a plain-language TLDR written for someone from another world — or another field.
It breaks down: - What I built - Why it matters - How to explain it to your obtuse martian friend
Because interpretability isn’t just for the models — it’s for the humans, too.

title: ailo-blog

🌀 Why This Blog Exists
This isn’t a devlog. It’s not a textbook. It’s a research-meets-narrative experiment — an engineering novel, one post at a time.
You’ll see code.
You’ll meet characters.
And you’ll slowly forget whether the agent is simulating a mind — or you are.

title: AILO Glossary
text:
Welcome to the AILO glossary, where we peel back the layers of AI terminology to reveal both the formal definitions and our more approachable AILO-style interpretations.





Formal: An autonomous entity that perceives its environment and takes actions to achieve specific goals.
AILO-style: A digital being that’s learning to walk before it can run (or think, or feel).








Formal: A programming construct that waits for and dispatches events or messages in a program.
AILO-style: The agent’s internal clock that keeps it from standing still like a statue.








Formal: An agent that selects actions based on the current percept, ignoring the rest of the percept history.
AILO-style: A digital creature that reacts first and asks questions later (or never).








Formal: A structured mental representation about the world held with some confidence.
AILO-style: A hunch the agent will probably act on… even if it’s wrong.


This glossary will grow as we add more layers to our simulated minds. Each term marked with 🧅 has both a formal definition and an AILO-style interpretation that makes it more approachable and fun.

title: Week 1: It’s Alive - Bootstrapping the Simulated Mind
text:
“Life, although it may only be an accumulation of anguish, is dear to me, and I will defend it.” — Frankenstein



In our first week, we’re focusing on building the bare-bones agent scaffold. This includes: - Basic movement capabilities - Environmental observation - Simple action loop - Logging system for debugging



### Agent 🧅



Formal: An autonomous entity that perceives its environment and takes actions to achieve specific goals.


AILO-style: A digital being that’s learning to walk before it can run (or think, or feel).



### Event Loop 🧅



Formal: A programming construct that waits for and dispatches events or messages in a program.


AILO-style: The agent’s internal clock that keeps it from standing still like a statue.



### Reflex Agent 🧅



Formal: An agent that selects actions based on the current percept, ignoring the rest of the percept history.


AILO-style: A digital creature that reacts first and asks questions later (or never).

Greetings, Earthling! Let me explain what we built this week in simple terms:
What We Built: A digital being that can move around and react to its environment. Think of it as a very simple robot that can walk and respond to basic commands.
Why It Matters: Before we can build complex AI that thinks and feels, we need to start with the basics. This is like teaching a baby to crawl before it can walk.
How to Explain It to Your Dog: Woof! (Translation: “It’s like a new puppy learning to move its legs for the first time. Simple, but necessary!”)
Stay tuned for more updates as we bring our first agent to life!

title: About
text:
AILO stands for AI is Like Onions — and this blog is an attempt to prove it.
It’s a solo engineering + research project that explores the construction of simulated minds inside a 2D sandbox world. Inspired by Stardew Valley, cognitive science, and interpretability research, AILO blends: - Code - Narrative - Emotion - And the occasional bug-ridden farm tool.

title: About
text:
This isn’t just about making an AI that works — it’s about building one that: - Plans with purpose - Remembers what mattered - Feels when ignored - Reflects on its regrets - Changes with experience
Each week, the agent gets a new cognitive upgrade. Each week, we test if it breaks everything.
